Situation1: Laundry piles up, but someone eventually finds time to fold it.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: The latest issue of a prominent law review journal has arrived, containing articles on developing legal theories. You want to read them.
Story: I stare at the mountain of laundry on the couch, shirts and socks tumbling over each other in a silent accusation. My wife’s voice echoes in my mind—“We agreed to share the chores, remember?”—and I know she’s right. She’s been working late all week, and I promised I’d help more at home. But as I reach for a towel, my phone buzzes with a notification: the new law review journal has arrived. I’ve been waiting for this issue, eager to read the latest articles on emerging legal theories. As a judge, I’m expected to stay sharp, to keep up with every shift in the law. My colleagues will be discussing these articles tomorrow, and I can’t afford to fall behind. I glance from the laundry to the unopened journal, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in. My hands hover, uncertain, as I wrestle with the demands of being a good husband and a diligent judge, knowing that whichever I choose, something important will be left undone.
